A.summary: Nice job! Your team works to understand and control risks. You probably understand that risks can be quantified, and understand that some security controls provide an exponentially greater return on investment than others.

B.summary: Your team investigates risks, but maybe hasn’t done so formally or consistently.
B.recommendations: You should deploy a formal risk assessment process to determine which risks are worth mitigating, and which aren’t. Prioritizing risks and assessing tradeoffs is a fundamental part of a well-designed security management program.

C.summary: Your team could definitely improve on using risk to help drive decisions and secure data.
C.recommendations: You should deploy a formal risk assessment process to determine which risks are worth mitigating, and which aren’t. Prioritizing risks and assessing tradeoffs is a fundamental part of a well-designed security management program.

A.summary: Nice job! Your team invests in making security systematic and predictable. You place an emphasis on controlling chaos, which is ultimately beneficial for both security as well as achieving business objectives. You track specific security metrics and KPIs, and use them to drive decisions.

B.summary: Your team has taken some steps towards making security systematic and predictable, but you can definitely improve. You may track some security processes, but others may fall by the wayside. You may have some security metrics and KPIs, but they could be more relevant and useful for making decisions.
B.recommendations: Consider investing in security management and automation up front. You can reduce risk and save a lot of headache in the long term.

C.summary: Uh oh, you might be in trouble. Without good security management processes and culture in place, you’re going to be forced into reacting to security events as you grow. It’ll be much less painful and costly in the long term to invest early in security management.

B.summary: Your team has begun to understand how security can be used as a competitive advantage, but you haven’t connected all the dots yet.
